Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The effect of dialect contact and social identity on fricative demerger

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Societal changes across the world, particularly in Europe, are altering long-standing traditional dialects. Many such dialects are converging towards national or regional standards. Varieties of Andalusian Spanish present an intriguing case study where two sounds that had been merged are now splitting (or demerging) back into two separate categories, a process known as demerger. In this case, ceceo, or the neutralization of orthographic and to the voiceless predorso-dental fricative [s¦È], in existence since medieval Spanish, is currently demerging into two separate sounds, [s] and [¦È], respectively, converging with the Castilian standard known as distinci¨®n. Ceceo and distinci¨®n each carry social value and the social identities of speakers are judged depending upon which norm they follow.

The present research documents the demerger in the Andalusian province of Huelva. It compares two speech communities: (i) the capital city of Huelva, which reflects the new, more cosmopolitan Europe of expanding social networks; and (ii) Lepe, an agricultural town of the province, reflecting an older, more provincial, Europe, but one with stronger social networks. This study seeks to answer the following: (1) which factors contribute most to the probability that a speaker will manifest a split rather than a merger (age, sex, local networks, education, profession, etc.); (2) what are the acoustic profiles of the coronal fricative consonants corresponding to various orthographic representations produced by speakers of each region; and (3) does this demerger impact certain words more than others? The research questions will be investigated through interview data, drawing on the methods and interpretive frameworks of variationist sociolinguistics, laboratory phonology, sociophonetics, social dialectology, and linguistic anthropology. The demerger of ceceo exemplifies the social pressures placed on speakers of local traditional dialects to converge towards more standard features, even if contrary to natural processes of language change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation examines the phonetic demerger of the traditional dialectal features of ceceo (the neutralization of orthographic s and z,ci,ce) to the voiceless dental fricative [sθ]), into two separate sounds, [s] and [θ], respectively, converging with the Castilian standard known as distinción. In order to examine this change-in-progress, the analysis focused on a reading passage and a word list from 80 speakers (40 male, 40 female; ages 18-87) from the city of Huelva and the nearby rural town of Lepe in Andalucía, Spain. The aim of the research was four-fold: (i) to provide a sociophonetic assessment of the demerger of ceceo in connection to sociolinguistic theories of mergers and splits; (ii) to investigate which linguistic and social factors promote the demerger of ceceo; (iii) to compare rural and urban speech communities in regards to the demerger; and finally, (iv) to determine the acoustic properties of these Andalusian coronal fricatives. The results indicate that both communities are demerging ceceo into distinción. The leaders of this change are females, younger, those with more educational attainment, those with service and professional oriented occupations, and those from Huelva. Although those from Huelva are more advanced in the change than Lepe, this does not reflect differences in the process of linguistic change, but rather differences in the rate of change due to their unique socioeconomic histories. Finally, those with distinción demonstrate a separation in phonemes with higher values for center of gravity and mean intensity for [s] and lower values for center of gravity and mean intensity for [θ], while those with ceceo demonstrate intermediate values for center of gravity and mean intensity.

This dissertation contributes new data to the analysis of phonetic mergers and splits in the context of dialect contact and large-scale societal change. The implications of this study are fourfold: (i) large scale-societal changes of increased dialect contact, increased education, and changes in sectors of employment, have created the social context for the convergence from traditional dialectal ceceo to standard Castilian distinción; (ii) the motivation for this community-wide split is inherently social, demonstrating the social pressures placed on speakers of local traditional dialects to converge towards more standard features, even if contrary to natural processes of language change; (iii) both urban Huelva and rural Lepe are moving from ceceo to distinción indicating that even smaller towns perceived as timeless carriers of dialectal features are susceptible to dialect convergence to regional or national standards; and, finally, (iv) the feature of ceceo undermines the phonological categorical approach between phonemes as it presents a gradient phonetic continuum between and overlapping with /s/ and /θ/.

The present study contributes to the on-going research of Andalusian Spanish, dialect contact and convergence, and mergers and splits. Specifically, this dissertation has broader impacts for multiple areas of linguistics:

Sociolinguistics: This dissertation provides a rigorous sociolinguistic analysis of an understudied area of Andalucía. The study presents a non-English example that confronts sociolinguistic claims on mergers/splits, indicating that more non-English examples should be incorporated into general sociolinguistic theory. Additionally, the study has promoted using quantitative sociolinguistic methodologies in a rural community, which are generally overlooked, as they are commonly assumed to be resistant to linguistic change.

Sociophonetics: As the majority of sociophonetics work has been done on English and vowels, this project fills a major gap in subsegmental analyses of Spanish and consonants. The current study has also contributed two methodological advancements for sociophonetics studies on fricatives and mergers/splits; a fricative plot (a way to visualize fricative phonetic properties) and a demerger index (a means of normalizing data and creating individual speaker demerger scores).

Phonetics and phonology: The detailed gradient differences in ceceo and distinción bolster phonetic claims against binary phonological theories of categorical differences. In particular, the current study has demonstrated that ceceo (and its split into distinción) demonstrates a gradient nature of sibilance as opposed to binary differences. In light of these findings, the study has proposed two separate phonetic continuums for Andalusian coronal fricatives.

Dialectology: Although Andalusian Spanish has been studied quite a bit in the traditional dialectology literature; this study highlights the need for more local empirical examinations. In addition, this study contributes to the rich literature of linguistic convergence induced by dialectal contact found in modern social dialectology.

While much work remains to be done to understand the lexical diffusion of the change, this study contributes to an ongoing scholarly conversation on Andalusian coronal fricatives, dialect contact and convergence, and variationist analysis of mergers and splits; and consequently promotes new directions for future research.
